Being persuaded that all things were and are created for the honor and glory of God, and that nothing was ever created in vain; and believing that man is no exception to this truth, but that above all other created things he was made for the same end; and also believing that every human life is a "living epistle to be read of all men"; and that no one is so humble that he cannot testify to the wonderful goodness, mercy, loving kindness and power of Almighty God, I sit down, under a conviction of duty, to record the history of a chequered life; a life, though humble, yet filled with evidences of that merciful loving kindness in Him who sufferers not a sparrow to fall to the ground without His knowledge. 
If some of the incidents and sketches recorded seem to be trivial or out of place I would simply say by way of explanation that my design is to show the current of the mind in the two different phases of my life; the period when in nature's darkness I followed the courses of the world; and the period when by God's grace

Here we remained but a few days, when we went to Philadelphia, and from thence we took up our journey upon horseback for Pittsburgh. I was but six weeks old when we left Philadelphia, and was carried in a basket before the saddle by one of the soldiers. The journey was a long and tedious one, over hills and through vallies and rivers, but God preserved all our lives and kept us in health to the end. 
A few days were spent in Pittsburgh to recruit and fit up the boats for the descent of the Ohio river, and the ascent of the Mississipi and Missouri, which were then navigated by keelboats only. At this time too the river banks were lined with many hostile tribes of Indians, but God was still with us, and we passed them all with little or no molestation. The details of this journey have passed from my memory, and therefore I must pass to the time to which memory carries me back.

With most persons who write their histories it is usual (whether it be for their own gratification, or for the public eye) either to pass lightly over the days of their childhood and commence at the time when ambition, or some other potent charm caused them to throw off the restraint imposed by parental rule and they enter the world of pleasure, toil and anxiety the undisputed  masters of their own wills and actions. In this I will not follow their example, for memory carries me back to a very early period and the incidents previous to that time have been so often related to me by old soldiers and domestics that few have slipped my recollection, although most of those incidents have nothing to do with me personally. I deem it unnecessary to enter into a detailed account of my parents. My father's galantry and bravery during the war of 1812-'15 is too well known to require eulogy from his son. Tippecanoe, Erie, Lundy's Lane, Brownstown, Detroit, Plattsburgh and many other spots known to fame as sacred to the cause of liberty, were never a disgrace to him. During the first summer of my residence at Fort St. Peters there was a grand review of the troops, on the occasion, I think, of the visit of the Inspector General. To get a better view of the parade I climbed to the top of a high stump. I soon discovered that this stump was partially hollow and nearly filled with what appeared to be dry leaves. Child like I took a stick and began to stir these leaves. Instantly I was completely enveloped by a cloud of bumble bees that soon covered me with their stings, from the pain of which I became frantic, dancing for a few moments upon the top of the stump like a showman's monkey under the whip, and then falling to the ground pursued by the bees. Previous to the killing of the first party of drovers, related above, the vigilance of my father had revealed to him evident signs of jealousy and turbulence among the Indians, and Wanata had declared himself opposed to the establishment of a military station in the Territory, it being in his estimation an infringement of the rights of his people, and he remonstrated decidedly against it. Remonstrance being in vain he assembled his warriors and sent them out in small parties to destroy every white man who should cross their paths. 
Satisfied that a more courageous system of warfare must be inaugurated if he would succeed in expelling the enemy he resolved to strike a decisive blow against the Fort itself. After endeavoring for some time to draw the garrison into an ambuscade without success he withdrew his warriors and made overtures for peace, and then formed a plan for its capture and massacre within the walls of the fort. With this this design he sent messengers to Col. Snelling requesting permission to enter the fort with a few of his principal warriors, for the purpose of having a "talk" to settle the differences between them. The request was granted; but Col. He was celebrated not only for his warlike character, but for his natural abilities as a man and a gentleman. In person he was tall, athletic and perfectly formed, having a decided majestic and dignified carriage. His dress was truly aboriginal, but neat, and even elegant. It consisted of a shirt of check calico well made and ruffled, a coat, leggins and moccosins of hansomely tanned deer skin ornamented with colored porcupine quills worked in hierogliphics, and the seams and borders fringed with colored loops, feathers, and hawk's bells. The coat and leggins were secured around the waist and, below the knees with try-colored sashes; the front of the coat being left open to show the silver ornaments fastened to the shirt front, which were presented to him by the United States and British governments. Around his neck he wore a necklas of griselly bear's claws, a trophy which he prized above all others, as the evidence of the greatest achievement of Indian prowess, and commemorating the death of a grisley bear which he had killed with his own hands. To kill but one of these ferocious beasts of the Rocky Mountains is considered by the Indians the crowning art of heroism; but Wanata had killed his score, and hence his elevation to then first place in the Dacotah nation. I will pause here to describe
as well as I can from memory, - the new fort/Snelling).
It was one of the best (if not the best) constructed
fortifications on the western frontier.  It
was built entirely of stone and surrounded by a 
high and massive wall, this wall on the east,
south, and west sides starting from the sides
of the hill upon which it was built, appeared,
from a distance, to be a portion of the steep
declivity.  The south front was defended by a 
semi-circular tower one story high, sufficiently

river, southwards, and what was called

the Minnesota, or St. Peters river, the main portion

several miles below.  A circular tower four or
five stories high, and pierced for about forty
guns, commanded a large tract of country to

is a charming spot called Coldwater, where
I spent many a delightful summers' day gathering

Wednesday, 18th. Surveyed Third Island, and killed two Massasanga[?] rattlesnakes with eight and ten rattles. One of these was killed in a very peculiar manner. coons. On the 7th we started out on duty but were obliged to return in consequence of the severity of the weather.
Sunday, 8th  It being a pleasant day I accompanied Lieut. L__ to Charity Islands, distant eighteen miles. Wandered about the island and picked up some specimens of chrystal and gypsum, or strantian. The form of this island is very peculiar, having four very acute angles and convex sides, forming four fine, deep, commodious harbors, in either of which vessels may ride with safety let the wind be in whatever quarter it may, or however violent. From this circumstance it derives its name.
Monday, 9th _ Commenced work where we left off on the 6th and surveyed to the camp. Passed Point au Chene, which is a low point, covered with a beautiful forest of oak, and from which a rocky bar extends for a mile or more into the Bay. Formerly, Voyageurs, on their way to Mackinaw crossed the Bay from this point. On the 10th the wind blew a gale, and the rain fell heavily. Capt Marsar, our hunter, killed a deer. This Capt. Marsar is a very peculiar man, a true hunter, and second only to Capt. Martin Scott as a rifleman. We attempted to move this day, before the storm came up, contrary to his advice, and the result was according to his prediction; every boat was swamped and we all had to swim to the shore,

like a man in an ague fit. The chainmen were running round the Island at a very brisk rate when all of a sudden, when the man at the hind end of the chain called out "stick," the shoemaker gave an agonising yell, sprang several feet backwards and, with his hair bristling all over his head, fell sprawling and kicking upon the ground. "He's seed a snack," bawled out one of the men, and on going up to the spot, sure enough there lay the ten rattler squirming and struggling on the ground wit the iron pin used as a marker piercing his neck. It was indeed a narrow escape, for the act of "sticking the pin" brought the man's hand within four inches of the reptile, and had it pierced him in any other part of the body he would have bitten the man, and death would have ensued before any remedy could have been applied.
Thursday, 19th _ Wind and rain kept us in camp. The evil of Pine Island is very rich and is cultivated by the Indians. 20th. Lieut. P__ removed the camp to Thread river, while Lieut. L__ surveyed three other small islands. After a hard day's work supped on clams from the bay. This is the first time I ever ate them, or knew of their having been eaten, and I was surprised to find them so delicious. They have more the consistency and the flavor of the oyster than the clam. I roasted them in the shell with salt and pepper.
